title: Acts Chapter 9 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 9 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 9 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 9.

questions.question: Who was breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord at the beginning of Acts 9?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 9:1 states that Saul was breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord.

questions.question: What was Saul's purpose for going to Damascus according to Acts 9?
options: To bring bound disciples to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To bring bound disciples to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 9:2 explains that Saul desired letters to Damascus to bring any followers of 'the way' bound to Jerusalem.

questions.question: What happened to Saul as he neared Damascus?
options: A light from heaven shined around him
He was arrested by the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: A light from heaven shined around him
questions.explanation: Acts 9:3 states that suddenly a light from heaven shined round about Saul as he came near Damascus.

questions.question: What question did the voice from heaven ask Saul?
options: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
Why do you seek to harm me?
Do you believe in the Son of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?
questions.explanation: Acts 9:4 records the voice asking Saul why he persecuted Him.

questions.question: Who did the Lord identify Himself as to Saul?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 9:5 records the Lord saying, 'I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.'

questions.question: How many days was Saul without sight after his encounter on the road?
questions.correctAnswer: Three days
questions.explanation: Acts 9:9 states Saul was three days without sight and neither ate nor drank.

questions.question: Who was the disciple in Damascus that the Lord spoke to in a vision about Saul?
questions.correctAnswer: Ananias
questions.explanation: Acts 9:10 names Ananias as the disciple whom the Lord spoke to in a vision about Saul.

questions.question: What did the Lord tell Ananias to do regarding Saul?
options: Go to the house of Judas and lay hands on Saul
questions.correctAnswer: Go to the house of Judas and lay hands on Saul
questions.explanation: Acts 9:11-12 instruct Ananias to go to Saul's house and lay hands on him so he may receive sight.

questions.question: True or False: Ananias was immediately willing to go to Saul without hesitation.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 9:13-14 shows Ananias hesitated because he had heard of Saul's evil deeds against the saints.

questions.question: What did the Lord say about Saul's purpose?
options: He is a chosen vessel to bear my name before Gentiles and kings
He is to remain in Damascus forever
He will lead the Jews against the Christians
questions.correctAnswer: He is a chosen vessel to bear my name before Gentiles and kings
questions.explanation: Acts 9:15 states Saul is chosen to bear God's name before Gentiles, kings, and Israel.

questions.question: What happened immediately after Ananias laid hands on Saul?
options: Scales fell from Saul's eyes and he received sight
questions.correctAnswer: Scales fell from Saul's eyes and he received sight
questions.explanation: Acts 9:18 describes that scales fell from Saul's eyes and he received sight immediately.

questions.question: What was Saul's first action after regaining sight?
options: He preached Christ in the synagogues
questions.correctAnswer: He preached Christ in the synagogues
questions.explanation: Acts 9:20 states Saul immediately preached that Jesus is the Son of God.

questions.question: How did the people who heard Saul preach react?
options: They were amazed and questioned if he was the one who persecuted Christians
questions.correctAnswer: They were amazed and questioned if he was the one who persecuted Christians
questions.explanation: Acts 9:21 records the amazement and suspicion about Saul's identity.

questions.question: True or False: Saul was accepted without fear by the disciples when he came to Jerusalem.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 9:26 explains the disciples were afraid and did not believe Saul was a disciple at first.

questions.question: Who took Saul to the apostles and explained his conversion and bold preaching?
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas
questions.explanation: Acts 9:27 states Barnabas brought Saul to the apostles and told them about Saul's conversion and preaching.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 9 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 9 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear after facing opposition for sharing their faith. Based on Acts 9, what biblical truth would you share about overcoming fear through faith and fellowship?
options: God provides faithful companions who encourage and support us
We must always face trials alone to prove our faith
Fear should be avoided by withdrawing from church fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: God provides faithful companions who encourage and support us
questions.explanation: Barnabas took Saul and brought him to the apostles, encouraging fellowship and boldness (Acts 9:27), demonstrating that God uses others to strengthen us. Also, the disciples helped Saul by lowering him in a basket to protect him (Acts 9:25). This teaches us that God provides support to overcome fear.

questions.question: How does the conversion of Saul in Acts 9 teach about the importance of obedience to God's calling despite past mistakes?
options: Obedience transforms us and uses us for God's purposes
Past mistakes disqualify us from serving God
We should wait until we are perfect before obeying God
God ignores our obedience if we have sinned
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience transforms us and uses us for God's purposes
questions.explanation: Saul obeyed Jesus' command to go into Damascus and was transformed into a chosen vessel to bear God's name (Acts 9:6,15). This shows that obedience enables transformation and use in God's service despite past sins (Acts 9:1-2, 9:20).

questions.question: A believer is discouraged because they feel their past sin is too great. What does Acts 9 teach about God's grace and purpose for those who repent?
options: God chooses and uses even those with a troubled past for His glory
Only those without sin can serve God effectively
Repentance is unnecessary for God's service
God does not forgive serious past sins
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses and uses even those with a troubled past for His glory
questions.explanation: God told Ananias that Saul was a chosen vessel to bear His name before the Gentiles and kings (Acts 9:15). Despite Saul’s past persecution, God had a purpose for him, showing grace and calling all believers to obedience (Acts 9:13-16).

questions.question: How does Ananias’ response to God's vision in Acts 9 teach about trusting God's plan even when it challenges our fears or biases?
options: We should trust and obey God even when His plans seem difficult or risky
We should only follow God when it is easy and safe
Doubting God’s plan is a sign of strong faith
Ignoring God’s instructions protects us from harm
questions.correctAnswer: We should trust and obey God even when His plans seem difficult or risky
questions.explanation: Ananias was hesitant because of Saul's reputation, but God commanded him to go and heal Saul (Acts 9:10-14). Ananias obeyed and was used by God to restore Saul’s sight and fill him with the Holy Spirit (Acts 9:17-18), showing trust in God's plan despite fear.

questions.question: What does Saul’s immediate preaching of Christ after his conversion teach us about the importance of evangelism and sharing the gospel?
options: New believers are called to boldly share their faith without delay
Evangelism should only be done by experienced leaders
Sharing faith is optional for new converts
One should wait many years before preaching
questions.correctAnswer: New believers are called to boldly share their faith without delay
questions.explanation: Saul immediately preached Christ in the synagogues after his conversion (Acts 9:20), demonstrating the urgency and importance of sharing the gospel. This boldness also caused amazement and opposition, highlighting the cost of faithful evangelism (Acts 9:21-22).

questions.question: A new believer is facing persecution for their faith. What practical lesson about perseverance can we learn from Saul's experience in Acts 9?
options: Perseverance through trials strengthens faith and witness
Persecution means God has abandoned you
Avoid all trials by hiding your faith
Only the strongest believers face persecution
questions.correctAnswer: Perseverance through trials strengthens faith and witness
questions.explanation: Saul faced plots to kill him and had to escape Damascus by night (Acts 9:23-25), yet he continued preaching boldly. This shows that perseverance amidst trials is vital for spiritual growth and witness (Acts 9:29-30).

questions.question: How does the healing of Aeneas by Peter in Acts 9 demonstrate God's power to restore and the role of faith in healing?
options: God heals through faith and the prayers of His servants
Healing is only physical and unrelated to faith
Sick people should not expect healing
God’s power to heal is limited
questions.correctAnswer: God heals through faith and the prayers of His servants
questions.explanation: Peter said, 'Jesus Christ maketh thee whole: arise,' and Aeneas was healed immediately (Acts 9:34). This shows God's power to heal through faith and the ministry of His servants, encouraging trust in God’s restoration (Acts 9:32-35).

questions.question: What does the raising of Tabitha (Dorcas) teach us about the value of serving others and generosity in the early church?
options: Serving others with good works is highly valued and recognized by God
Generosity is optional and not important in Christian life
Only men can serve in the church
questions.correctAnswer: Serving others with good works is highly valued and recognized by God
questions.explanation: Tabitha was known for good works and almsdeeds (Acts 9:36). Peter raised her from the dead, and many believed in the Lord (Acts 9:40-42). This shows the importance of generous service as an expression of faith and love.

questions.question: How does the passage where Peter prays and raises Tabitha demonstrate the role of prayer and dependence on God in serving others?
options: Prayer is essential before acting in ministry and service
Actions alone without prayer are sufficient
Prayer should be private and not connected to ministry
Dependence on God is unnecessary if you have skill
questions.correctAnswer: Prayer is essential before acting in ministry and service
questions.explanation: Peter knelt and prayed before raising Tabitha (Acts 9:40), showing reliance on God’s power through prayer in ministry. This teaches us to seek God’s guidance and strength in serving others (Acts 9:38-41).

questions.question: True or False: Saul was immediately accepted by all the disciples in Jerusalem after his conversion.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: When Saul came to Jerusalem, the disciples were afraid of him and did not believe he was a disciple (Acts 9:26). Only Barnabas vouched for him and helped him join the apostles (Acts 9:27).

questions.question: True or False: The churches experienced rest and growth as a result of walking in the fear of the Lord and the comfort of the Holy Ghost.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 9:31 states that the churches had rest and were edified while walking in the fear of the Lord and the comfort of the Holy Ghost, resulting in multiplication.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Saul was led into Damascus after his encounter with Jesus because he was _______ and could not see.
questions.correctAnswer: blind
questions.explanation: Saul was three days without sight after the heavenly encounter and was led by the hand into Damascus (Acts 9:8-9). This physical blindness symbolizes the need for spiritual sight and guidance.

questions.question: How does the account of Saul’s baptism and receiving the Holy Spirit teach us about spiritual transformation and renewal?
options: Baptism and receiving the Holy Spirit symbolize new life and empowerment for service
Spiritual transformation happens only through works
The Holy Spirit is unrelated to Christian life
Renewal is a gradual process without clear moments
questions.correctAnswer: Baptism and receiving the Holy Spirit symbolize new life and empowerment for service
questions.explanation: After Ananias laid hands on Saul, scales fell from his eyes, he was baptized, and filled with the Holy Ghost (Acts 9:17-18), marking his spiritual transformation and empowerment for ministry.

questions.question: What does the story of Saul’s escape from Damascus show about God’s provision and the importance of the church community in protecting believers?
options: The disciples helped Saul escape by lowering him in a basket, showing care and protection
Believers should always face danger alone
The church has no role in protecting its members
Escape from trials is a sign of weak faith
questions.correctAnswer: The disciples helped Saul escape by lowering him in a basket, showing care and protection
questions.explanation: When Saul’s enemies tried to kill him, disciples lowered him in a basket through the city wall to protect him (Acts 9:23-25), illustrating the church’s role in caring for and safeguarding its members.

questions.question: How does Peter’s ministry in Lydda and Joppa demonstrate the importance of serving and ministering to the local church community?
options: Peter traveled to visit and heal the saints, showing active care and ministry
Church leaders should remain isolated from their communities
Ministry is only about preaching, not serving the sick
Local community service is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Peter traveled to visit and heal the saints, showing active care and ministry
questions.explanation: Peter passed through Lydda and healed Aeneas (Acts 9:32-35), then went to Joppa and raised Tabitha (Acts 9:36-43), demonstrating active ministry and care within the local church community.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 9 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 9.

questions.question: What was Saul's initial mission when he went to Damascus according to Acts 9?
options: To bring bound disciples to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To bring bound disciples to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Acts 9:1-2 states Saul desired letters to Damascus to bind any followers of 'this way' and bring them to Jerusalem.

questions.question: In Acts 9, what phenomenon caused Saul to fall to the ground near Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: A light from heaven
questions.explanation: Acts 9:3 describes a sudden light from heaven shining around Saul, causing him to fall.

questions.question: What question does the voice from heaven ask Saul on the road to Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: Why do you persecute me?
questions.explanation: Acts 9:4 records the voice asking Saul, 'Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?'

questions.question: Who identifies Himself to Saul during the encounter on the road to Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord Jesus
questions.explanation: Acts 9:5 reveals that the Lord says, 'I am Jesus whom thou persecutest,' identifying Himself to Saul.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'hard for thee to kick against the pricks' in Acts 9:5 symbolize?
options: The futility of opposing divine will
The pain of his past persecutions
The difficulty of traveling on rough roads
questions.correctAnswer: The futility of opposing divine will
questions.explanation: The phrase uses a Greek proverb meaning resistance is futile, indicating Saul’s opposition to God's plan is self-defeating.

questions.question: How long was Saul without sight after his encounter with Jesus?
questions.correctAnswer: Three days
questions.explanation: Acts 9:9 states Saul was blind for three days, neither eating nor drinking.

questions.question: Who was the disciple in Damascus that received a vision instructing him to visit Saul?
questions.correctAnswer: Ananias
questions.explanation: Acts 9:10-11 tells of the Lord speaking to Ananias in a vision to go to Saul.

questions.question: What was Ananias's initial reaction to the Lord’s command to visit Saul?
options: He questioned because of Saul’s reputation
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned because of Saul’s reputation
questions.explanation: Acts 9:13-14 records Ananias expressing concern about Saul’s past persecution of Christians.

questions.question: How does the Lord describe Saul’s role despite his past actions?
options: A chosen vessel to bear His name
questions.correctAnswer: A chosen vessel to bear His name
questions.explanation: Acts 9:15 calls Saul a chosen vessel to proclaim God's name before Gentiles, kings, and Israel.

questions.question: What immediate physical change happened to Saul after Ananias laid hands on him?
options: His scales fell from his eyes and he regained sight
He was given the Holy Spirit visibly
questions.correctAnswer: His scales fell from his eyes and he regained sight
questions.explanation: Acts 9:18 describes scales falling from Saul’s eyes and him receiving sight immediately.

questions.question: After his conversion, what did Saul do 'straightway' in Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: Preached Christ in the synagogues
questions.explanation: Acts 9:20 states Saul immediately preached that Jesus is the Son of God in the synagogues.

questions.question: How did the Jews in Damascus react to Saul’s preaching?
options: They were amazed and questioned if he was the persecutor
questions.correctAnswer: They were amazed and questioned if he was the persecutor
questions.explanation: Acts 9:21 shows their amazement and disbelief that Saul was the former persecutor.

questions.question: What strategy did Saul’s enemies use to try to kill him in Damascus?
options: Laying wait and watching the city gates
Challenging him to a public debate
questions.correctAnswer: Laying wait and watching the city gates
questions.explanation: Acts 9:24 describes the Jews watching the gates day and night to kill Saul.

questions.question: How was Saul able to escape from Damascus when his enemies sought to kill him?
options: Let down in a basket by the city wall
questions.correctAnswer: Let down in a basket by the city wall
questions.explanation: Acts 9:25 states the disciples lowered Saul in a basket through an opening in the wall.

questions.question: True or False: When Saul returned to Jerusalem, all disciples immediately welcomed him without fear.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 9:26 states the disciples were afraid and did not believe Saul was a disciple.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 9 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 9 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was Saul's initial attitude towards the disciples of the Lord before his conversion?
options: He was a protector of the disciples
He was indifferent to the disciples
He was threatening and seeking to kill the disciples
questions.correctAnswer: He was threatening and seeking to kill the disciples
questions.explanation: Acts 9:1 describes Saul as 'breathing out threatenings and slaughter against the disciples of the Lord,' showing his hostile stance against them. This is consistent with Psalms 35:1 where the wicked oppose God's people, and Jeremiah 1:18 where God warns of opposition. Also, John 15:18-20 teaches believers will face persecution, and 2 Corinthians 12:10 speaks about suffering for Christ.

questions.question: What authority did Saul obtain to persecute the followers of Jesus in Damascus?
options: Letters from the high priest to the synagogues
A mandate from the Sanhedrin in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Letters from the high priest to the synagogues
questions.explanation: Acts 9:2 states that Saul requested letters from the high priest to the synagogues in Damascus to arrest those of 'this way.' This indicates the religious authority sought for persecution. This aligns with Jesus' own warnings about religious leaders' opposition (Matthew 10:17), and Old Testament examples of priests exercising authority (Numbers 16:40).

questions.question: What supernatural event happened to Saul on the road to Damascus?
options: A light from heaven shone around him and he heard a voice
He was blinded by the sun
He received a vision of angels
questions.correctAnswer: A light from heaven shone around him and he heard a voice
questions.explanation: Acts 9:3-4 recount that a light from heaven suddenly shone around Saul and he heard a voice saying, 'Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me?' This manifestation reveals divine intervention consistent with other biblical theophanies (Exodus 3:2-6, Acts 26:13). The voice of Jesus identifying Himself shows Christ's divine authority (John 10:27).

questions.question: What does Jesus mean when He says to Saul, 'It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks'?
options: It is difficult to oppose God's will
It is painful to rebel against the law
It is futile to resist divine correction
It is illegal to persecute the saints
questions.correctAnswer: It is futile to resist divine correction
questions.explanation: In Acts 9:5, the phrase 'It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks' is an idiom meaning resistance to God's plan is futile and self-harming. This is echoed in Proverbs 3:11-12 about God's discipline, Hebrews 12:5-11 teaching correction for believers, and Isaiah 55:8-9 about God's higher ways.

questions.question: How long was Saul blind after his encounter with Jesus on the road to Damascus?
questions.correctAnswer: Three days
questions.explanation: Acts 9:9 states Saul was without sight and did not eat or drink for three days. The number three is significant biblically (Jonah 1:17, Jesus' resurrection after three days in Matthew 12:40), often symbolizing a period of transformation or judgment.

questions.question: What role did Ananias play in Saul’s conversion?
options: He baptized Saul immediately upon meeting him
He was the high priest who sent Saul
He was the disciple who restored Saul's sight and filled him with the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: He was the disciple who restored Saul's sight and filled him with the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Acts 9:10-17 describes Ananias receiving a vision from the Lord to go to Saul, lay hands on him to restore his sight, and fill him with the Holy Ghost. This demonstrates the role of the church in the process of salvation (Hebrews 10:24-25), and the work of the Holy Spirit in regeneration (John 3:5-8).

questions.question: Why did Ananias initially hesitate to obey the Lord's command to visit Saul?
options: He feared Saul's reputation for persecuting Christians
He doubted the vision was from God
He was not a disciple at the time
questions.correctAnswer: He feared Saul's reputation for persecuting Christians
questions.explanation: Acts 9:13-14 shows Ananias expressing concern about Saul's known persecution of Christians and authority to bind those who call on Jesus. This highlights the fear believers had for Saul and contrasts with God's sovereign purpose (Isaiah 55:8-9) in using Saul for salvation.

questions.question: According to the Lord, what was Saul’s divine purpose after his conversion?
options: To bear Jesus’ name before Gentiles, kings, and Israel
To rebuild the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: To bear Jesus’ name before Gentiles, kings, and Israel
questions.explanation: Acts 9:15 articulates Saul as a 'chosen vessel' to bear Christ's name before Gentiles, kings, and children of Israel, underscoring the universal mission of the gospel as foretold in Isaiah 49:6 and affirmed in Luke 24:47 and Romans 1:5.

questions.question: What immediate action did Saul take after regaining his sight and being filled with the Holy Spirit?
options: He preached that Jesus is the Son of God in synagogues
He returned to Jerusalem to confront the apostles
He wrote letters to other believers
questions.correctAnswer: He preached that Jesus is the Son of God in synagogues
questions.explanation: Acts 9:20 records Saul immediately preaching Christ as the Son of God, demonstrating the transformative power of salvation and the urgency of evangelism, consistent with Jesus’ Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20) and early church practice (Acts 2:36-41).

questions.question: How did the Jewish listeners in Damascus react to Saul’s preaching?
options: They welcomed him as a teacher
They were amazed and questioned if he was the one who persecuted Christians
They immediately believed and followed him
questions.correctAnswer: They were amazed and questioned if he was the one who persecuted Christians
questions.explanation: Acts 9:21 describes the amazement and skepticism of the Jews who remembered Saul's prior persecution of Christians, highlighting the radical nature of Saul's conversion which underscores the transformative power of grace (2 Corinthians 5:17).

questions.question: What strategy did Saul’s enemies employ to kill him in Damascus?
options: They publicly challenged him to a debate
They put guards on the city gates day and night to watch for him
They reported him to the Roman authorities
They spread false rumors about him
questions.correctAnswer: They put guards on the city gates day and night to watch for him
questions.explanation: Acts 9:24 indicates Saul’s enemies watched the gates day and night to kill him, showing the dangerous opposition to the gospel and the presence of persecution (John 15:20), which the early church anticipated and endured.

questions.question: How was Saul able to escape from Damascus after the plot against his life was discovered?
options: He was hidden in a basket and lowered through the city wall
He disguised himself as a Gentile
questions.correctAnswer: He was hidden in a basket and lowered through the city wall
questions.explanation: Acts 9:25 reports that Saul’s disciples lowered him in a basket through an opening in the wall to escape danger. This reflects the protective care of the church and God's providence (Psalm 91:11) in preserving His servants.

questions.question: What was the initial reaction of the Jerusalem disciples when Saul tried to join them?
options: They were afraid and did not believe he was a disciple
They sent him back to Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: They were afraid and did not believe he was a disciple
questions.explanation: Acts 9:26 explains the fear and disbelief of the Jerusalem disciples due to Saul’s past persecution of Christians, illustrating the challenge of trust and restoration within the community of faith (2 Corinthians 2:7-8).

questions.question: Who vouched for Saul to the apostles in Jerusalem and what did he declare?
options: Peter; that Saul was a disciple
Barnabas; how Saul had seen the Lord and preached boldly
John; that Saul had been baptized
James; that Saul had a letter of recommendation
questions.correctAnswer: Barnabas; how Saul had seen the Lord and preached boldly
questions.explanation: Acts 9:27 states Barnabas introduced Saul to the apostles, testifying to his encounter with the Lord and bold preaching, emphasizing the role of Christian fellowship and endorsement in ministry (Ephesians 4:11-13).

questions.question: What miraculous healing did Peter perform in Lydda, and what was its immediate effect on the people?
options: He healed a blind man; many believed in the Lord
He healed Aeneas of palsy; all turned to the Lord
He raised a dead man; the city was saved from an earthquake
He cast out a demon; the synagogue was filled with joy
questions.correctAnswer: He healed Aeneas of palsy; all turned to the Lord
questions.explanation: Acts 9:33-35 recount Peter healing Aeneas who had been bedridden for eight years, leading many in Lydda and Saron to turn to the Lord. This aligns with Jesus’ healing ministry (Luke 5:17-26) and early church signs (Mark 16:17-18) confirming the gospel.
